title: Classics in Political Thought
description: Where do the core tenets of Western political philosophy come from? In this course students will trace the development of political philosophy by examining Ancient Greek plays (e.g., Antigone, Medea) and foundational political texts (e.g., Plato's Republic, Aristotle's Politics) which set the stage for modern Western political thought (Machiavelli and after).

title: Government and Business
description: How do the relations between government, business, and civil society function? Focusing on Canada in comparative context, students will study national and sub-national government policies relating to key debates in socio-economic development.

title: Canadian Government & Politics
description: An examination of Canada's federal system, parliamentary government, and national political processes, such as the party system, interest groups, the electoral system, and voting behavior.

title: Special Subjects
description: Course topics vary. Topics may include international trade and cultural literacy, and the practice of politics. [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of 10 times.]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: At least 0.5 unit in PSCI; Level at least 3B

title: Special Subjects
description: Course topics vary. Topics may include the ethics of war, the 2018 U.S. election, and U.S. foreign policy. [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of 10 times.]
requirementsDescription: Prereq: At least 0.5 unit in PSCI; Level at least 3B

title: Globalization
description: How is globalization changing the nature of politics? Students will examine leading political debates surrounding the forces that promote and resist global integration in the contemporary age.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: PSCI 150 or INTST 101; Level at least 2A

title: Introduction to the Modern Middle East
description: This course examines the modern political history of the Middle East, with an emphasis on international affairs. It examines the colonization of the Middle East, the rise of national self-determination and nation-states, enduring Arab-Israeli conflicts, the Cold War, and the impact of U.S. foreign policy in shaping the modern Middle East.

title: Global Governance
description: Global governance is governing beyond the state.  An examination of diverse problems - global warming, international human rights, terrorism, property rights disputes, and health crises - which transcend borders and demand cooperative global solutions.

title: Politics of International Trade
description: What political institutions create, underpin, or otherwise affect international trade? Through theoretical and empirical study, students will examine important influences over the formulation of trade policy, focusing on distributional and efficiency considerations, interest groups, and institutional arrangements.

title: Cultural Politics and Indigenous Practices
description: How does research in Indigenous communities proceed? What cultural questions and methodological issues arise? Students will study colonialism, power, and voice in the context of Indigenous struggles within the Canadian nation-state and around the globe.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: At least 0.50 unit in PSCI course at the 200-level or above; Level at least 2B

title: The Cultural Politics of Israel/Palestine
description: What are the key features of the cultural politics that underlie the Israel/Palestine conflict? Students will study the everyday lives of those affected by the violence to understand the complex narratives of violence, peace, and human rights that circulate across the region, as well as among those in diaspora and exile.
